data.title: Nothing happens when clicking "Go to Declaration"
data.body:
I've tried right-clicking a method call in both Ruby and PHP and then selecting "Go to Declaration". Nothing happens. Nothing shows up in the developer tools console. The same thing happens in safe mode.

Using 0.129.0 on OS X

data.title: Model EditorView::setPlaceholderText
data.body: Less dependence on the editorView!

data.title: Make cursor / selection events consistent
data.body: `onDidChangeSelectionRange` and `onDidChangeCursorPosition` passed different data to their call backs. This makes them consistent.

data.title: Support package activation events with global command registry
data.body: Currently, commands registered with `atom.commands` don't work correctly with package activation events.

data.title: Rename Git -> GitRepository
"set-version" task failed, when build Atom on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS.
data.body:
When I try to build Atom v0.129.0 on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS (x86_64), the building task always "Aborted due to warnings." when "Running 'set-version' task".

I check out branch with command like guide saide:
git checkout $(git describe --tags `git rev-list --tags --max-count=1`)

$ script/build --build-dir ./out

data.title: Remove lintian errors
data.body:
Correct errors generated when running lintian against the deb package.
- [x] arch-dependent-file-in-usr-share
- [x] changelog-file-missing-in-native-package
- [x] embedded-library
- [x] extended-description-is-empty
- [x] no-copyright-file
- [x] python-script-but-no-python-dep
- [x] shlib-with-executable-bit
- [x] unstripped-binary-or-object
- [x] wrong-file-owner-uid-or-gid

Closes #3596

data.title: Cursor getBeginningOfCurrentWordBufferPosition seems to produce incorrect results
data.body:
Take this snippet of code:

```
var express = require('express'),
```

When I place my cursor right before the first 'r' in require, and I call `getBeginningOfCurrentWordBufferPosition()`, I get the '=' as the beginning of the current word...but there's a space in between.

When I place my cursor right before the first 'r' in require, and I call `isInsideWord()`, I get true..but I'm really at the beginning of the word.

Am I just expecting different results, or are these methods actually a little confusing..?

data.title: Notify when file has changed outside of atom on unsaved buffer
data.body:
today i worked on a project with sublime text and atom. i edited a file on sublime text, saved the changes and opened atom(the same file). both editors were open at the same time. but when i go to atom, there was no change detection to the file and all the changes, made in sublime text, were gone.

what i miss is a popup, mentioning that the file has changed and ask whether reloading.

data.title: Crash on Ubuntu when dragging a Firefox window over Atom
data.body:
Atom Version: 0.129.0
Video of me triggering the bug: http://ara.sh/private/atom-crash.ogv
Reproducible every time.

Environment:
Ubuntu 14.04 (all updates installed as of filing this issue)
Unity desktop environment

Repro steps:
1) Launch atom from the Terminal
2) Open a Firefox window (or use an existing one)
3) Drag the Firefox tab anywhere over the Atom window

Actual behavior:
It crashes

Expected behavior:
Not crash :-)

Additional Information:
The terminal prints out the following after the crash:

```
[7950:0920/180947:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(161)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://code.google.com/p/chromium/wiki/LinuxSUIDSandboxDevelopment for more information on developing with the sandbox on.
[7950:0920/180947:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(189)] GTK theme error: Unable to locate theme engine in module_path: "pixmap",
ATTENTION: default value of option force_s3tc_enable overridden by environment.
App load time: 88ms
[7984:0920/180947:INFO:renderer_main.cc(227)] Renderer process started
[7950:0920/180948:INFO:CONSOLE(18)] "Window load time: 778ms", source: /opt/atom/resources/app/src/window-bootstrap.js (18)
The program 'atom' received an X Window System error.
This probably reflects a bug in the program.
The error was 'BadAtom (invalid Atom parameter)'.
  (Details: serial 1360 error_code 5 request_code 20 minor_code 0)
  (Note to programmers: normally, X errors are reported asynchronously;
   that is, you will receive the error a while after causing it.
   To debug your program, run it with the --sync command line
   option to change this behavior. You can then get a meaningful
   backtrace from your debugger if you break on the gdk_x_error() function.)
```

data.title: No Alt Gr (right Alt) support on Windows
data.body:
There are several keyboard layouts (i.e. Latin American) that make use of the right `Alt` key (labeled as `Alt Gr`) as a special helper key, different from the left `Alt`.
For example, in my keyboard I use `Alt Gr` + `Q` to print the `@` symbol.
This is not working on Atom 0.129.0, Windows 8.1 Pro, American English with a Latin American keyboard layout. The right `Alt` is simply handled the same as the left `Alt`, with no special functions.
There are several quite common characters I'm not able to use, such as `\`, `@`, `~`, etc.

data.title: Add view provider API to Workspace
data.body:
/cc @atom/core Worth review since I'm adding a major API here.

This PR is another step in move away from SpacePen and towards HTML 5 custom elements. It adds two methods to `Workspace`:
## ::getView(object)

This method can be called with any object in the workspace in order to get a view. You can use it to get the view corresponding to the workspace itself, panes, or pane items.  It _always_ returns a DOM node rather than a SpacePen view. In the near future, it will return HTML 5 custom elements for all our views in core, but for now it just returns the root DOM node of SpacePen views with a `__spacePenView` expando property pointing back at the view. A branch is already in progress to convert core views to custom elements.

``` coffee
editorView = atom.workspace.getView(atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor())
paneView = atom.workspace.getView(atom.workspace.getActivePane())

# this one is weird but worth it for consistency. getting the workspace view
# should be rare once the panel APIs are in place.
workspaceView = atom.workspace.getView(atom.workspace)
```
## ::addViewProvider

This is the other half of `::getView`. If you add a model object as a pane or panel item, the workspace's view needs to know how to present it on screen. This is how you teach workspace to do that:

``` coffee
atom.workspace.addViewProvider
  modelConstructor: TextEditor # Future name of Editor
  viewConstructor: TextEditorElement # Future custom element for TextEditor
```

Custom elements are required to have a `::setModel` method so the model can be assigned since element constructors don't take arguments.

You can also provide a `createView` factory method which is passed the model. This mechanism provides more flexibility but is less convenient if all you want to is build a custom element.
## Next Steps

Next up: converting our core views to custom elements, which includes workspace views and text editors. Every model object in the workspace should have its view constructed via the new provider API. After that, we'll be in position to switch to custom tag names and explore using the shadow DOM.

data.title: Settings View Styling Issue
data.body:
I'm trying out writing a UI theme for Atom, and as I tried styling the settings menu, I found out that the package description text in the settings view is of class `text-subtle`, making it look weird when I try to style it, because both the description and the less important text get faded (with the `text-subtle` styling rules). Shouldn't be of type `text` or something like that?

![text-subtle](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4193418/4340613/dca61aee-402f-11e4-85e8-93d1e10fb37c.png)

data.title: Add matching of Atom.app more stable
data.body: I have this file on my Mac `/Users/timosand/Library/Application Support/com.github.atom.ShipIt/update.85PyXs3/Atom.app` and my `mdfind` returns it. It seems to be a common one, so I thought to remove it from the list to be sure that it selects the right Atom.app

data.title: Soft tabs setting is ignored
data.body: I'm running on 0.129.0. The soft tabs option in Settings seems to be completely ignored. Instead, all tabs are hard. Affects safe mode as well.

data.title: Final docs pass
data.body:
This cleans up and reorganizes the docs based on the conversation @nathansobo and I had today. 

This is just docs changes. Mostly renaming sections, and moving methods between sections.

data.title: Fail focused specs on CI
data.body:
This ensures focused specs never end up as green builds on PRs and will fail master builds when focused specs are pushed to master.

/cc @nathansobo @benogle You guys okays with this? Today we had another focused spec checked in and it seems like it happens enough that we should just just fail them immediately on CI when they are checked in.

data.title: Atom Range API doesn't seem to create a valid range
data.body:
I'm trying to get the text in the range from the beginning of the file to the cursor position.

Just for brevity, assume cursor is the first cursor in the editor, and textBuffer is the editor's buffer.

```
var beginningOfRange = [0, 0];
var endOfRange = cursor.getBufferPosition();
var selectionRange = new Range(beginningOfRange, endOfRange);

textBuffer.getTextInRange(selectionRange); // returns ""
textBuffer.getTextInRange(textBuffer.getRange()); // returns the file as a string
```

Am I doing something wrong?

By the way, when inspecting the ranges created, it seems that the `getRange` returns a Range instance with a start and end point, and creating a new Range manually doesn't.

data.title: Specs fail if editor's emitter is disposed on destroy
data.body:
Calling `@emitter.dispose()` from `Editor::destroyed` causes the following spec to fail:

```
>> EditorComponent
>>   hiding and showing the editor
>>     when the editor is hidden when it is mounted
>>       it defers measurement and rendering until the editor becomes visible
>>         Error: Emitter has been disposed
>>           at Emitter.module.exports.Emitter.on (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/node_modules/event-kit/lib/emitter.js:31:15)
>>           at Editor.module.exports.Editor.onDidChange (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/src/editor.coffee:208:14)
>>           at [object Object].module.exports.React.createClass.observeEditor (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/src/editor-component.coffee:353:23)
>>           at [object Object].boundMethod [as observeEditor] (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/node_modules/react-atom-fork/lib/ReactCompositeComponent.js:1295:21)
>>           at [object Object].module.exports.React.createClass.componentDidMount (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/src/editor-component.coffee:175:6)
>>           at CallbackQueue.mixInto.notifyAll (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/node_modules/react-atom-fork/lib/CallbackQueue.js:75:22)
>>           at ReactReconcileTransaction.ON_DOM_READY_QUEUEING.close (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/node_modules/react-atom-fork/lib/ReactReconcileTransaction.js:88:26)
>>           at ReactReconcileTransaction.Mixin.closeAll (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/node_modules/react-atom-fork/lib/Transaction.js:214:42)
>>           at ReactReconcileTransaction.Mixin.perform (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/node_modules/react-atom-fork/lib/Transaction.js:155:16)
>>           at [object Object].ReactComponent.Mixin.mountComponentIntoNode (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/node_modules/react-atom-fork/lib/ReactComponent.js:388:19)
>>           at Object.<anonymous> (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/node_modules/react-atom-fork/lib/ReactMount.js:313:25)
>>           at Object._renderNewRootComponent (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/node_modules/react-atom-fork/lib/ReactPerf.js:57:21)
>>           at Object.ReactMount.renderComponent (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/node_modules/react-atom-fork/lib/ReactMount.js:379:32)

```
